label: Children’s, Teenage & Educational

children.label: Children’s / Teenage fiction & true stories
children.notes: Use with: (all YF* codes) ALWAYS with appropriate 5A* Reading Age/Level Qualifier, and 5X where appropriate, to indicate explicit material for older readers; YF* codes may be used with PLACE 1* and TIME PERIOD 3* Qualifiers where these aspects are particularly pertinent and significant; use with & before relevant YN* codes for fiction with specific themes or topics not sufficiently indicate in YF*; use with YDC for fiction anthologies; use with & before appropriate YX* code for fiction dealing with specific social or personal issues; use X* codes for comic book fiction, See also: XADC XAKC XAMC XAMF XAMG

children.label: Children’s / Teenage fiction: special features & related items

Use for: genre fiction, usually published on a monthly basis, short, in clearly delineated lines and with a certain number published every month. Use with: other YF* code indicating genre or type. YFZR codes should never be the main subject code

children.label: Children’s / Teenage fiction: inspired by or adapted from
children.notes: Use for: stories that were published as spin-offs or companions to pre-existing non-book media or merchandise, for example story books based on a popular film franchise, toy, an online game or a TV series. Do NOT use for titles that were subsequently made into films etc. Use with: other YF* code indicating genre or type. YFZV codes should never be the main subject code

children.label: Children’s / Teenage fiction: companion works
children.notes: Use for: companion works to popular children’s or teenage fiction series or titles, typically uncritical, such as an atlas of a mythical world, a compendium of characters, a guide to the series, etc. Use with: other Y* codes or on its own as appropriate

children.label: Children’s / Teenage: general interest
children.notes: Use for: (all YN* codes) all general interest material not covered elsewhere & not designed specifically for school use. children.notes: Class here: works of literary & non-genre fiction widely regarded as ‘classic’ and typically published at least 50 years ago, but where available, prefer ‘classic’ headings for genre fiction, See also: DBS* FFC FLC

children.notes: Use for: highly fictionalised accounts of the lives of real people (including fictionalised autobiographies). Use with: FV where applicable, See also: DN*

children.notes: Use for: any fiction set in an ideal, dysfunctional or degraded society. Use with: FL* or other F* codes as appropriate

children.notes: Use for: any fiction, apart from Fantasy or SF, set in an imagined world that might have emerged had key historical events happened differently eg outcome of WW2

children.notes: Use for: works of crime fiction widely regarded as ‘classic’ and typically published at least 50 years ago

children.notes: Use for: stories where the main investigator is not an official police or judicial investigator

children.notes: Use for: mysteries set in rural or traditional communities featuring minimal violence & typically amateur sleuths

children.notes: Use with: S* codes to indicate specific sport featured

children.notes: Use for: thrillers incorporating scientific, technological (including computing), medical, etc elements as important parts of the narrative

children.notes: Use for: thrillers featuring traditions of ancient, secret or esoteric knowledge, such as Holy Grail, etc

children.label: Historical adventure fiction
children.notes: Use for: adventure novels set in past times; prefer specific FJM* code if applicable. Use with: PLACE 1* and/or TIME PERIOD 3* Qualifiers to indicate setting as appropriate

children.label: Sea stories
children.notes: Class here: naval & maritime fiction

children.notes: Class here: classic gothic horror. Use for: horror & ghost stories widely regarded as ‘classic’ and typically published at least 50 years ago

children.label: Contemporary horror & ghost stories
children.notes: Use for: horror set in the present day or contemporary settings, typically published in the last 50 years

children.label: Classic science fiction
children.notes: Use for: science fiction widely regarded as ‘classic’ and typically published at least 50 years ago

children.notes: Class here: dieselpunk, retrofuturism. Use for: science fiction based on an alternative world where 19th century steam power has emerged as the dominant technology

children.label: Science fiction: cyberpunk / biopunk
children.notes: Use for: science fiction based on marginalised or low-life characters in a highly technologically advanced society or focused on the implications of biotechnology or genetic engineering

children.label: Science fiction: military
children.notes: Use for: science fiction set within the military or where organised use of weaponry is central to the plot, See also: FLS

children.label: Science fiction: space opera
children.notes: Use for: science fiction set in space, usually with advanced cultures & technology

children.label: Science fiction: aliens / UFOs
children.notes: Class here: first contact, alien invasion

children.label: Science fiction: space exploration
children.notes: Class here: colonisation of space

children.label: Epic fantasy / heroic fantasy
children.notes: Class here: high fantasy

children.label: Fantasy romance
children.notes: Use for: fantasy stories using many of the elements and conventions of the romance genre but that remain primarily & recognisably a fantasy story, See also: FRV FRT

children.label: Dark fantasy
children.notes: Use for: fantasy stories with darker & frightening themes, often incorporating elements of horror or that have a gloomy & threatening atmosphere or a sense of horror & dread

children.label: Contemporary fantasy
children.notes: Use for: fantasy set in the present day or contemporary settings

children.label: Myths & fairy tales
children.notes: Class here: myths & legends, folk & fairy tales or fables told in a story form. Use for: modern retellings in novel form or collections of these type of traditional stories aimed primarily at adults, See also: DBS* QRS* JBGB YFJ

children.label: Erotic fiction
children.notes: Use for: stories of an erotic nature that deal explicitly with sexual relationships and themes, that are not primarily a romance story. Do NOT use with FRX. Use with: INTEREST Qualifier 5X as appropriate, See also: FRX

children.label: Contemporary lifestyle fiction
children.notes: Class here: ‘chick lit’, ‘lad lit’, ‘romantic comedy’, ‘feel good’ fiction. Use for: stories set in the present day or contemporary settings, dealing with everyday themes or lifestyles, usually in a light-hearted manner

children.label: Contemporary romance
children.notes: Use for: romance where main characters live & work in a world most readers can understand, with modern conveniences and current social mores

children.label: Romance: wholesome
children.notes: Class here: sweetheart, clean & cosy romance. Use for: romance that does not contain any strong language or physical intimacy. Use with: FW for religious romance, if appropriate, & with 5P* values from INTEREST Qualifiers as appropriate

children.label: Historical romance
children.notes: Use for: romance stories set in the past (typically before the writer’s lifetime), where the time period is a significant or essential part of the story, and that portray the spirit, manners, and social conditions of that time with realistic detail (eg Regency romances). Use with: PLACE 1* and/or TIME PERIOD 3* Qualifiers to indicate setting as appropriate

children.label: Romance: ‘western’, rural or ‘outback’
children.notes: Class here: cowboy romance. Use for: romance that takes place in very rural environments, often set on farms, ranches or in small rural communities, usually far from any city

children.label: Romance in uniform
children.notes: Class here: military, armed services, firefighters, police, pilots, cabin crew etc.. Use for: romance stories where one or more of the main protagonists is in a job that means wearing a formal uniform

children.label: Romance: medical
children.notes: Use for: romance stories featuring doctors, nurses, etc

children.label: Romance: fantasy & paranormal
children.notes: Class here: vampire romance, were/ shifter romance. Use for: a romance story which blends elements from the fantasy genre or features mythical creatures or supernatural elements but remain primarily & recognisably a romance story. Use with: FM* codes if appropriate

children.label: Dark romance
children.notes: Use for: genre romance stories where the themes are dark, often exploring themes of evil or horror, usually featuring an anti-hero or non-heroic characters and/or distressing situations

children.label: Erotic romance
children.notes: Use for: romance fiction which contains explicit sexual content, but which remains primarily & recognisably a romance story. Do NOT use with FP. Use with: INTEREST Qualifier 5X as appropriate, See also: FP

children.label: Family life fiction
children.notes: Use for: novels of domestic or small-scale family life, See also: FT

children.label: Generational sagas
children.notes: Class here: family sagas. Use for: novels which chronicle the fortunes of a family or families often over generations. Do NOT use for Icelandic or Norse sagas, See also: FS

children.label: Humorous fiction
children.notes: Use for: fiction where humour is the primary aim & feature except prefer genre-specific ‘humorous’ headings where available. Use with: other F* codes as appropriate

children.label: Satirical fiction & parodies
children.notes: Use for: humorous fiction which is satirical and/or which parodies existing fiction, genres or writers, See also: WHP FYH

children.label: Historical fiction
children.notes: Use for: stories set in the past (typically before the writer’s lifetime), where the time period is a significant or essential part of the story and that portray the spirit, manners, and social conditions of that time with realistic detail. Use with: other F* codes as appropriate. Use with: PLACE 1* and/or TIME PERIOD 3* Qualifiers to indicate setting as appropriate. Prefer genre-specific ‘historical’ headings where available, See also: FFH FJH FMH FRH

children.label: Religious & spiritual fiction
children.notes: Use for: fiction designed to promote a particular religious, spiritual or visionary message. Use with: 5PG* values from INTEREST Qualifiers as appropriate, or where unavailable, a QR* or VX* code. Use with: other F* codes, for example FR - for Religious romance novels

children.label: Fiction: narrative themes
children.notes: Use with: (all FX* codes) other F* codes indicating genre or type, to indicate the underlying narrative theme of a work of fiction. FX* codes should never be the primary or main subject code

children.label: Narrative theme: Coming of age
children.notes: Class here: bildungsroman

children.label: Narrative theme: Love & relationships
children.notes: Use for: fiction where a relationship or love is the central theme but not a genre romance novel

children.label: Narrative theme: Environmental issues
children.notes: Use for: fiction that addresses a specific environmental issue as a central theme

children.label: Narrative theme: Death, grief, loss
children.notes: Use for: fiction where a loss or the experience of grief is a central theme

children.label: Narrative theme: Interior life
children.notes: Use for: fiction which places particular emphasis on interior characterization, and on the motives, feelings and thoughts of characters. Prefer FHX for psychological thrillers

children.label: Narrative theme: Politics
children.notes: Use for: fiction where political concerns are the underlying narrative theme including political allegories. Prefer FHP for political thrillers

children.label: Narrative theme: Sense of place
children.notes: Use for: fiction set in a real location (often but not necessarily rural or historic), where the setting very deeply pervades the work to the extent that it could not be set anywhere else; eg the French tradition of ‘roman du terroir’. Use with: PLACE Qualifiers 1*

children.label: Narrative theme: Social issues
children.notes: Use for: fiction that addresses a specific social problem or issue as a central theme. Use with: other Non-fiction codes especially JBF* codes to give more detail of main social issue

children.label: Fiction: special features
children.notes: Use with: (all FY* codes) with other F* code indicating genre or type. FY* codes should never be the primary or main subject code

children.label: Epistolary fiction
children.notes: Use for: fiction written in a series of documents, letters, diaries, emails, blogs etc

children.label: Fiction: pastiche
children.notes: Use for: fiction written deliberately in the style of another (typically earlier) author (as homage rather than parody), often as a sequel to a novel written by, or using a popular character created by, the original author, See also: FUP

children.label: Fiction: mashup
children.notes: Use for: fiction which combines a pre-existing text, often a classic novel, with another contrasting genre, such as horror, into a single narrative. Use with: other F* or non-fiction codes to indicate component elements, See also: FUP

children.label: Category fiction
children.notes: Class here: ranobe (Japanese-style light novels). Use for: the kind of romance, science fiction or other types of genre fiction, usually published on a monthly basis, short, in clearly delineated lines and with a certain number published every month. Use with: other F* code indicating genre or type. FYR codes should never be the primary or main subject code

children.label: Fiction in translation
children.notes: Use for: fiction in translation from another language. Do NOT use PLACE or LANGUAGE Qualifiers to describe the detail of the original language, this would be described elsewhere and not using Thema. You may still use a PLACE Qualifier if it is relevant to the plot or setting of the book. Use with: F* codes to ensure classification is meaningful beyond the translation of the work itself. FYT codes should never be the primary or main subject code

children.label: Fiction: inspired by or adapted from
children.notes: Use for: stories that were published as spin-offs or companions to pre-existing non-book media or merchandise, for example, novels inspired by a popular film franchise, an online game or a TV series. Do NOT use for titles that were subsequently made into films etc

children.label: Fiction companions
children.notes: Use for: companion works to popular fiction series or titles, typically uncritical, such as an atlas of a mythical world, a compendium of characters, a guide to the series, etc, See also: DSR XR*

children.notes: Class here: constellation & star guides, non-specialist guides to astronomy & space, including space exploration, See also: PG* TTD

children.label: Local history
children.notes: Use for: popular accounts of the history of a specific locality, generally only of local interest. Use with: PLACE 1* & TIME PERIOD 3* Qualifiers as appropriate

children.label: Nostalgia: general
children.notes: Use for: popular works with fond, uncritical view of past times. Use with: other code indicating subject where appropriate, eg WGF “Trains & railways: general interest”

children.label: Places in old photographs
children.notes: Use for: collections of early or vintage photographs relating to a specific place or places. Use with PLACE 1* & TIME PERIOD 3* Qualifiers wherever possible, See also: AJC

children.label: Family history, tracing ancestors
children.notes: See also: NHTG

children.label: Travel & holiday
children.notes: Use with: (all WT* codes) the most specific PLACE 1* Qualifiers available, as appropriate

children.label: Travel & holiday guides
children.notes: Use for: general travel guides, lists of places to visit, ‘best of’ guides, that are not in a more specific category and that remain primariliy guidebooks. Use with: the most specific PLACE 1* Qualifiers available, plus INTEREST 5* Qualifier, or another subject code, to indicate a specialised guidebook. For example, 5PS to indicate holidays aimed at a particular group, See also: WJS WTM

children.label: Travel guides: food & drink regions
children.notes: Class here: travel guides based around local foods, wine-producing regions etc. Use with: PLACE 1* Qualifier as appropriate and WB* for detail on area of food & drink concerned, See also: WTHR

children.label: Travel guides: activity holidays
children.notes: Class here: travel guides for active holidays. Use with: SZ* codes to indicate the activity involved

children.label: Travel guides: holidays with children / family holidays
Travel guides: hotel & holiday accommodation guides
children.notes: Use for: ‘where to stay’ guides, recommendations of specific establishments

children.label: Travel guides: beaches & coastal areas
children.notes: Use with: PLACE 1* Qualifier codes as appropriate

children.label: Travel guides: museums, historic sites, galleries etc
Travel guides: restaurants & cafes
children.notes: Class here: Inns, bars, pubs, bistros for food / drink. Use for: ‘where to eat/ drink’ guides, recommendations of specific establishments, See also: WTHD

children.label: Travel guides: routes & ways
children.notes: Class here: guides to long distance routes, such as footpaths, trails, cycleways, waterways, highways, bridleways, etc. Use with: PLACE 1* Qualifier codes as appropriate plus subject codes, such as SZ*, where appropriate

children.label: Travel guides: cruises
children.notes: Class here: river & sea cruises. Use with: PLACE 1* Qualifier codes as appropriate

children.label: Language phrasebooks
children.notes: Use with: LANGUAGE Qualifier 2* as appropriate, See also: CJBT

children.label: Classic travel writing
children.notes: Use for: travel writing published at least 50 years ago or widely regarded as ‘classic’

children.label: Expeditions: popular accounts
children.notes: Class here: popular accounts of expeditions & exploration, See also: RGR

children.label: Places & peoples: general & pictorial works
children.notes: Use for: illustrated and inspirational travel books, books about places to visit, etc, that are NOT primarily guidebooks. Use with: the most specific PLACE 1* Qualifiers available plus INTEREST 5* qualifier or another subject code when the title has a specialised theme, See also: AJC

children.label: Travel maps & atlases
children.notes: See also: RGX*

children.label: Travel maps
children.notes: Use for: all folded maps, other than city street maps & motorists’ road maps, for general & travel use

children.label: Street maps & city plans
children.notes: Class here: maps & books of maps of cities, towns & streets for general use

children.label: Gift books
children.notes: Use for: small books, typically of a decorative, humorous or inspirational nature, intended to be given as gifts rather than read by the purchaser, See also: YZG

children.label: Stationery items
children.notes: Use for: any printed stationery item, diaries, calendars, posters, kits, postcard packs, bookmarks, etc. Use with: another code indicating subject where possible

children.label: Blank stationery items
children.notes: Class here: blank notebooks, autograph books and other content-free items

label: Graphic novels, Comic books, Cartoons
notes: Use with: a ‘type’ from XA*, followed where possible & appropriate, with a ‘genre’ from XQ* for graphic novels & comic books

children.label: European tradition graphic novels
children.notes: Use for: In the European tradition, graphic novels are typically one-off publications, rather than part of a series, generally for an adult audience, often with distinctive graphics & more literary textual content, usually serious rather than humorous; they are works published originally as graphic novels, not adaptations of textual works

children.label: European tradition comic books, Bandes dessinées
children.notes: Use for: In the European tradition, comic books or ‘bandes dessinées’ are typically published in ongoing series, often featuring the same characters, as distinct from ‘one-off’ graphic novels

children.label: European comic books: general, classic, all ages
children.notes: Class here: ‘bandes dessinées tout public’, classic comic books for all ages

children.label: American / British style comic books & graphic novels
children.notes: Use for: graphic novels & comic books in the American / British tradition

children.label: American comic books: classic, Golden Age
children.notes: Class here: early & classic ‘Golden Age’ characters for all ages

children.label: Manga & Asian style comics
children.notes: Use for: This sequence includes all Japanese comic books (Manga) plus those from other Asian countries including Korean (Manhwa) & Chinese (Manhua)

children.label: Manga: Kodomo
children.notes: Use for: Manga for children, boys & girls, age around 6 to 10

children.label: Manga: Shōjo
children.notes: Use for: Manga designed for young & teenage girls, age around 10 to 15

children.label: Manga: Shōnen
children.notes: Use for: Manga designed primarily for young & teenage boys, age around 10 to 15

children.label: Manga: Seinen
children.notes: Use for: Manga designed for young adult men, from about 15 to 30 years old. Use with: Qualifier 5X as appropriate

children.label: Manga: Josei
children.notes: Use for: Manga designed specifically for young adult women

children.label: Manga: Yaoi
children.notes: Class here: boys‘ love (BL). Use for: Manga featuring young male homosexual relationships but for a young female readership

children.label: Manga: Bara
children.notes: Class here: Men’s Love (ML) manga. Use for: manga focusing on male same-sex love, usually created by gay men for a gay audience. Use with: Qualifier 5X as appropriate

children.label: Manga: adult (erotic, extreme violence)
children.notes: Use for: Manga designed for adults featuring scenes of an overtly adult nature only suitable for an aware and mature audience. Use with: other XAM* codes if appropriate & Qualifier 5X as appropriate, See also: XAMX2

children.label: Manga: hentai manga
children.notes: Use for: Manga designed for adults (over 18 years), of an extreme erotic or pornographic nature. Use with: Qualifier 5X as appropriate, See also: XAML

children.label: Manga: Yuri
children.notes: Class here: girls‘ Love. Use for: Manga featuring young female homosexual relationships often (but not exclusively) for a young female readership

children.label: Graphic novel / Comic book: memoirs, true stories & non-fiction
children.notes: Class here: ‘bandes dessinées d’auteur’, Slice of life, biographies, politics, travel

children.label: Graphic novel / Comic book: literary adaptations
children.notes: Use for: adaptations of pre-existing literary works into graphic form

children.label: Graphic novel / Comic book: inspired by or adapted from
children.notes: Use for: stories that were published as spin-offs or companions to pre-existing non-book media or merchandise, for example story books based on a popular film franchise, an online game or a TV series. Do NOT use for titles that were subsequently made into films etc

children.label: Graphic novel / Comic book: crime, mystery & thrillers
Graphic novel / Comic book: action & adventure
Graphic novel / Comic book: super-heroes & super-villains
Graphic novel / Comic book: science fiction
Graphic novel / Comic book: fantasy, esoteric
children.notes: Use for comic books featuring traditions of mythical, secret or esoteric knowledge

children.label: Graphic novel / Comic book: anthropomorphic / animal stories
Graphic novel / Comic book: school / college life
children.notes: Use with: 5LJ code as appropriate

children.label: Graphic novel / Comic book: adult
children.notes: Use for: comic books designed for adults featuring scenes of an overtly adult nature or dealing with graphic themes only suitable for an aware, mature audience. Use with: Qualifier 5X plus other X* codes as appropriate

children.label: Graphic novel / Comic book: adult – erotic
children.notes: Use for: comic books designed for adults featuring scenes of an overtly erotic nature or dealing with graphic sexual themes only suitable for an aware mature audience. Use with: Qualifier 5X plus other X* codes as appropriate

children.label: Graphic novel / Comic book: adult – extreme violence / gore
children.notes: Use for: comic books designed for adults featuring scenes of an overtly violent or gory nature or dealing with graphic or disturbingly violent themes only suitable for an aware mature audience. Use with: Qualifier 5X plus other X* codes as appropriate

children.label: Graphic novel & comic books: guides & reviews
children.notes: See also: DSR FZ

children.label: Manga guides & reviews
children.notes: See also: DSR FZ

children.label: Strip cartoons
children.notes: Use for: collections of typically humorous cartoons, in 3–5 panels, usually originally published in newspapers or magazines
